Title:
Two new species of Sidera (Hymenochaetales, Basidiomycota)
from southwest China
Keywords:
phylogenetic analysis, polypore, Rickenellaceae, taxonomy,
two new taxa, wood-rotting fungi
Abstract:
Two new wood-inhabiting fungi in the order
Hymenochaetales, Sidera xxx sp. nov. and S. yyy sp. nov. are described
and illustrated from China based on morphological and molecular
evidence. The two species were found from Tibet of southwest China, and
grow on rotten gymnosperm woods or charred gymnosperm roots. S. xxx is
characterized by annual, resupinate basidioma with a cream to salmon and
occasionally shiny pore surface, angular pores (79 per mm), a dimitic
hyphal system, and lunate basidiospores measuring 33.5 × 0.91.1 μm. S.
yyy is characterized by annual, resupinate basidioma with a white to
cream fresh pore surface which become cream to honey-yellow and shiny
upon drying, round pores (78 per mm), a dimitic hyphal system, and
lunate basidiospores measuring 2.93.1 × 11.1 μm. The phylogenetic
analysis based on the combined 2-locus dataset [5.8S + nuc 28S rDNA
(nLSU)] shows that the two species belong to Sidera and they are
morphologically compared with related species, respectively. An
identification key to 16 accepted species of Sidera in worldwide is
provided in the paper.
